Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it would therefore be beneficial to explain that the analysis of underlying inflation pressures took a wide range of indicators into account and went well beyond core inflation.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence explains the ECB's analysis of underlying inflation pressures, but does not indicate a specific stance or policy action."

 \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: according to a purely mechanical update of the latest short-term inflation projections, in the near term inflation was expected to be higher than projected in december and would likely remain above 2% for the rest of the year.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:57:11,921 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that inflation is expected to be higher than projected and remain above the 2% target, suggesting that the ECB may need to take measures to control inflation, such as increasing interest rates."
}

demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the light of the confirmation of the medium-term inflation outlook, members agreed that the june 2018 monetary policy decisions remained appropriate and called for a reaffirmation of the prevailing policy posture.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reaffirms the existing monetary policy stance, indicating no change in interest rates or other policy actions."

of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was important for communication to emphasise that the incoming data confirmed that the euro area economy was proceeding along a solid and broad-based growth path and underlined that risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook could still be assessed as broadly balanced, but uncertainties related to global factors remained prominent.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:57:26,932 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence emphasizes a solid and broad-based growth path, with balanced risks, indicating a neutral stance, as it neither suggests a need for monetary policy action nor expresses concerns about the economy."
}

relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while fiscal policy was expected to be expansionary in 2021 and 2022, members considered that the prospects for 2023 were more uncertain.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the uncertainty of fiscal policy prospects in 2023, but does not provide a clear indication of the ECB's stance or action, making it neutral."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was considered worrisome that, despite the stabilisation in oil prices, market-based inflation expectations had not picked up from their low levels.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence expresses concern that market-based inflation expectations remain low, suggesting that the economy may need stimulus, which is a dovish stance."

\\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: banks’ profits had recovered to levels seen before the pandemic, despite continued pressure on net interest margins.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",

housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: questions were raised as to how realistic it was to assume that containment measures would be reduced as early as the second quarter and it was pointed out that, depending on the further evolution of the pandemic, weakness in activity might continue well into the second quarter and beyond.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence expresses uncertainty about the effectiveness of containment measures and suggests that economic weakness might persist, implying a need for accommodative monetary policy."

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, the argument was made that the financial markets’ reaction to the governing council’s october decision and communication had contributed to a loosening of financial conditions, which had reversed some of the tightening that had occurred in the wake of the september meeting.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:57:51,334 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the financial markets' reaction to the ECB's decision has led to a loosening of financial conditions, implying a more accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: measures of systemic stress, volatility and market liquidity had returned to close to their levels before the failure of silicon valley bank (svb).\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while the pull-back in euro area growth in the first half of the year could largely be attributed to weaker external demand, after exceptionally strong external trade in 2017, the point was made that the moderation in annual rates of growth over the projection horizon reflected convergence towards growth in line with potential.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the moderation in annual rates of growth, which is attributed to convergence towards growth in line with potential, indicating a neutral stance."

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the april 2016 bank lending survey for the euro area pointed to improving loan supply conditions for enterprises and improving loan demand across all loan categories.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",

Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off
