Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: although risk-free rates and gdp-weighted sovereign bond yields had increased, it was observed that this had occurred mostly on account of higher expected inflation and a better outlook for the global economy.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions higher expected inflation, which suggests that the ECB may want to contract the money supply to combat inflation, indicating a hawkish stance."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: more generally, a significant part of the current weakness in manufacturing was likely to be of a structural nature, which would have different implications for the evolution of inflation, particularly as previous downward revisions to potential output growth might prove insufficient.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:58:13,276 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the current weakness in manufacturing is structural, implying a potential downward revision to potential output growth, which may lead to lower inflation and a more dovish monetary policy stance."
}

stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, non-performing loans remained a factor constraining credit expansion in some countries.\n                '}]

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, the steady absorption of economic slack gave grounds for increased confidence that price pressures would gradually take hold.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the economy is growing and absorbing slack, which may lead to increased price pressures, indicating a hawkish stance."
}

to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the ratio of net operating surplus to value added had increased further in the fourth quarter of 2015.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in view of the prevailing uncertainties and the large costs of bringing inflation down once it had become entrenched, it was argued that it was preferable to tighten monetary policy further than to not tighten it enough.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests tightening monetary policy to prevent inflation from becoming entrenched, indicating a hawkish stance."

of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the point was made that some moderation in growth was naturally to be expected, in line with the experience of other reopening economies.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: therefore, while there was wide agreement that there were no signs of a wage-price spiral, it was argued that current wage growth was clearly not consistent with a 2% inflation target, even when taking into account trend improvements in productivity.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence suggests that current wage growth is not consistent with a 2% inflation target, implying that inflation may be higher than desired, which may lead the ECB to take hawkish actions."

increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, this was not the case for the indicator of domestic inflation, which remained strong and was likely to reflect more persistent pressures on services prices, which had a high wage content.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates strong domestic inflation and persistent pressures on services prices, which may lead to higher inflation, prompting the ECB to consider decreasing the money supply."
}

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: concerns were nevertheless expressed that some of the downside risks to growth, as identified in the previous monetary policy meeting, in particular related to emerging market economies, had already partly materialised and were likely to affect negatively the outlook for euro area growth.\n                '}]

fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: real gdp had risen by 0.4%, quarter on quarter, in the second quarter of 2015, following a rise of 0.5% in the previous quarter.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports a moderate growth in real GDP, indicating a stable economic growth, which is a neutral stance."

stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, "label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a return to the pre-pandemic path in the labor market, suggesting a recovery, which may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance."

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was remarked that weakening the credibility of the fiscal framework also entailed a risk of a negative impact on the effectiveness of the expanded app through heightened uncertainty adversely affecting expectations and risk premia.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights the risk of a negative impact on the effectiveness of the expanded asset purchase program, implying that the ECB may need to adopt a more accommodative stance to mitigate this risk."
}

to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: commentators associated these developments with an increase in the uncertainty about the outcome of the 23 june referendum on uk membership of the european union.\n                '}]

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, while recent market volatility had not materially changed the assessment of the economic outlook, continued elevated uncertainty called for alertness and a readiness to respond, if necessary.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence expresses a cautious tone, calling for alertness and readiness to respond, but does not indicate a specific direction for monetary policy, maintaining a neutral stance."

is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank
